headline: The Software Rout Is Spreading Pain to the Debt Markets
summary: The steep selloff in software stocks is spreading to the debt market.  Pressured by growing worries about the disruptive potential of new AI coding tools, shares of large software companies such as Salesforce and ServiceNow have been sliding for months.

headline: Salesforce Army Megadeal Tests AI Vision And Leadership Stability
summary: Salesforce (NYSE:CRM) secured a US$5.6b, 10-year contract with the US Army, expanding its role as a core software provider to a major government customer. The deal coincides with leadership changes, including departures at Tableau and Slack, as the company responds to rising concerns about AI-driven disruption in enterprise software. Investors are weighing the long-term implications of deeper public sector ties against questions about Salesforce's organizational stability and product...

headline: 'Software-mageddon' unlikely to be broad-based, market expert says
summary: STORY: Investors have unloaded shares of companies such as ServiceNow and Salesforce on worries that rapidly improving AI tools could eat into demand for traditional software, squeezing profit margins across the sector.As for how things will shake out, Dhargalkar said that "like most market disruptions and downturns, and even upswings, it's never clear in the moment.""For example, some of the larger enterprise firms, software firms, they may actually find AI to be an enabling tool rather than a disruptive tool," he explained. "Whereas it's possible that for smaller SaaS (software as a service) or single-point type of solutions, they may have a much harder time overcoming this perception that there will be internally built software that can compete with external solutions for a lot of these enterprises."

raw.headline: 'Software-mageddon' unlikely to be broad-based, market expert says
raw.summary: STORY: Investors have unloaded shares of companies such as ServiceNow and Salesforce on worries that rapidly improving AI tools could eat into demand for traditional software, squeezing profit margins across the sector.As for how things will shake out, Dhargalkar said that "like most market disruptions and downturns, and even upswings, it's never clear in the moment.""For example, some of the larger enterprise firms, software firms, they may actually find AI to be an enabling tool rather than a disruptive tool," he explained. "Whereas it's possible that for smaller SaaS (software as a service) or single-point type of solutions, they may have a much harder time overcoming this perception that there will be internally built software that can compete with external solutions for a lot of these enterprises."

headline: Anthropic releases AI upgrade as market punishes software stocks
summary: Technology startup Anthropic on Thursday launched what it called an improved artificial intelligence model, days after its product advances helped ​kick-start a selloff of traditional software stocks.  The San Francisco-based lab, which is backed ‌by Amazon.com and Alphabet's Google, said its Claude Opus 4.6 model is an upgrade to the Opus 4.5 ‌model released in November.  The new AI can work on tasks for longer and more reliably, while showing gains related to coding and finance, Anthropic said.

raw.headline: Anthropic releases AI upgrade as market punishes software stocks
raw.summary: Technology startup Anthropic on Thursday launched what it called an improved artificial intelligence model, days after its product advances helped ​kick-start a selloff of traditional software stocks.  The San Francisco-based lab, which is backed ‌by Amazon.com and Alphabet's Google, said its Claude Opus 4.6 model is an upgrade to the Opus 4.5 ‌model released in November.  The new AI can work on tasks for longer and more reliably, while showing gains related to coding and finance, Anthropic said.

headline: Lockheed Martin Balances Defense Growth And New Wildfire Technology Venture
summary: Lockheed Martin (NYSE:LMT) secured a Foreign Military Sales contract to supply IRST21 Legion-ES infrared sensing systems to Taiwan's Air Force, making Taiwan the first international partner for this technology. The company also launched EMBERPOINT LLC, a new wildfire detection and response venture with PG&E, Salesforce, and Wells Fargo. The initiative focuses on AI, autonomous systems, and command-and-control tools. For investors watching Lockheed Martin at a share price of $602.76, these...

headline: US software stocks stabilize after bruising selloff on AI disruption fears
summary: Shares of U.S. software and data services companies steadied on Thursday after a bruising selloff earlier this week that was triggered by fears that fast-advancing artificial intelligence tools could ​upend the sector.  ServiceNow was up 0.1%, Salesforce slipped 0.2%, while Microsoft dropped 1.8% in premarket trading after sharp ‌falls earlier this week.  The S&P 500 software and services index has shed more than $800 billion in market value over the past six sessions.

raw.headline: US software stocks stabilize after bruising selloff on AI disruption fears

ServiceNow was up 0.1%, Salesforce slipped 0.2%, while Microsoft dropped 1.8% in premarket trading after sharp ‌falls earlier this week.  The S&P 500 software and services index has shed more than $800 billion in market value over the past six sessions.

headline: Is Salesforce (CRM) Now Offering Value After A Sharp 42% Share Price Slide?
summary: If you are wondering whether Salesforce at around US$199 a share looks like a bargain or a value trap, you are not alone. The stock has seen sharp moves recently, with a 12.5% decline over the last 7 days, a 22.2% decline over the last 30 days, and a 42.3% decline over the last year, although the 3 year return sits at 19.0%. These swings have kept Salesforce in the spotlight, as investors weigh its role in enterprise software and customer relationship management against changing expectations...

headline: Trillion-Dollar Tech Wipeout Ensnares All Stocks in AI’s Path
summary: Nothing, though, quite rivals the rout rippling through stock and credit markets this week.  In the span of two days, hundreds of billions of dollars were wiped off the value of stocks, bonds and loans of companies big and small across Silicon Valley.  “I don’t think it is an overreaction,” said Michael O’Rourke, chief market strategist at Jonestrading.
